title: Inhibitory effects of polystyrene microplastics on caudal fin regeneration in zebrafish larvae *
abstract: Microplastic pollution is pervasive in aquatic environments, but the potential effects of microplastics on aquatic organisms are still under debate. Given that tissue damage is unavoidable in fish and the available data mostly concentrate on healthy fish, there is a large chance that the ecotoxicological risk of microplastic pollution is underrated. Therefore, in this study, the effects of microplastics on the regenerative capacity of injured fish were investigated using a zebrafish caudal fin regeneration model. After fin amputation at 72 h post fertilization, the larvae were exposed to polystyrene microplastics (0.1 e10 mg/L) with diameters of 50 or 500 nm. Microplastic exposure significantly inhibited fin regeneration, both morphologically and functionally. Furthermore, the signaling networks that regulate fin regeneration, as well as reactive oxygen species signaling and the immune response, both of which are essential for tissue repair and regeneration, were altered. Transcriptomic analyses of the regenerating fin confirmed that genes related to fin regeneration were transcriptionally modulated in response to microplastic exposure and that metabolic pathways were also extensively involved. In conclusion, this study demonstrated for the first time that microplastic exposure could disrupt the regenerative capacity of fish and might eventually impair their fitness in the wild.

abstract.text: Microplastic pollution is pervasive in aquatic environments, but the potential effects of microplastics on aquatic organisms are still under debate. Given that tissue damage is unavoidable in fish and the available data mostly concentrate on healthy fish, there is a large chance that the ecotoxicological risk of microplastic pollution is underrated. Therefore, in this study, the effects of microplastics on the regenerative capacity of injured fish were investigated using a zebrafish caudal fin regeneration model. After fin amputation at 72 h post fertilization, the larvae were exposed to polystyrene microplastics (0.1 e10 mg/L) with diameters of 50 or 500 nm. Microplastic exposure significantly inhibited fin regeneration, both morphologically and functionally. Furthermore, the signaling networks that regulate fin regeneration, as well as reactive oxygen species signaling and the immune response, both of which are essential for tissue repair and regeneration, were altered. Transcriptomic analyses of the regenerating fin confirmed that genes related to fin regeneration were transcriptionally modulated in response to microplastic exposure and that metabolic pathways were also extensively involved. In conclusion, this study demonstrated for the first time that microplastic exposure could disrupt the regenerative capacity of fish and might eventually impair their fitness in the wild.

body_text.text: Since the first synthetic plastics appeared in the early 1900s, the past 60 years have witnessed the explosion upon the global production (SAPEA, 2019; Geyer et al., 2017) . However, given their recalcitrant nature and the low recycling rate (Geyer et al., 2017) , plastics accumulate in the environment and ultimately pose a daunting challenge for the global ecosystem as near-permanent contamination (SAPEA, 2019; da Costa et al., 2016; Geyer et al., 2017) . Therefore, plastic pollution is of heightened concern and has been considered a top environmental problem comparable to climate change (Avery-Gomm et al., 2018; Eerkes-Medrano et al., 2015) .

Due to the combination of physical, chemical and biological processes, the plastics present in the environment will eventually degrade to microplastics (Granby et al., 2018; Ivleva et al., 2017) , defined as plastic particles with sizes below 5 mm (Arthur et al., 2009) . Microplastics are also purposefully manufactured, including microbeads for personal care products (Ivleva et al., 2017; Rochman et al., 2015) . It has been reported that microplastic pollution are present in virtually all environmental niches, including freshwater and marine ecosystems, as the aquatic environment represents a sink for a large proportion of microplastics (Wilcox et al., 2015) . Therefore, it is highly likely that aquatic organisms will encounter these emerging contaminants, resulting in potential ecotoxicological consequences. Existing evidence has demonstrated that microplastic exposure can elicit several adverse effects on fish, including gastrointestinal damage, disturbances in energy metabolism, altered behavior performance, endocrine disruption, oxidative stress, DNA damage, and so on (SAPEA, 2019; Barboza et al., 2018; de Sa et al., 2018; Pannetier et al., 2020) .
However, the current knowledge about microplastic toxicity remains limited, even with conflicting data and inconclusive findings (SAPEA, 2019; Foley et al., 2018) .

Multicellular organisms, including fish, are quite fragile, and damage to tissues or organs is inevitable across their lifetime (Mathew et al., 2009; Yoshinari and Kawakami, 2011) . Therefore, the ability to restore tissue function and morphology is critical, and any interruption will possibly hinder their fitness and survival in the wild (Mathew et al., 2009; Sun et al., 2019) . On the other hand, injured organisms are hypothesized to be more susceptible to the effects of environmental contaminants. However, to date, studies regarding the toxicity of microplastics have mostly concentrated on healthy organisms rather than injured ones, potentially underrating the detrimental consequences of microplastic pollution at the population level. In addition, it is now firmly established that microplastic exposure results in direct physical harm, including internal abrasions and internal and external wounds (Horton et al., 2017; Ivleva et al., 2017) , which highlights the necessity of exploring the effects of microplastics on the capacity for repair and regeneration in injured aquatic organisms, including fish.

The zebrafish (Danio rerio) caudal fin regeneration model has served as the gold standard for regenerative studies over the last two decades (Gemberling et al., 2013; Sehring et al., 2016) , and the effects of several contaminants, including dioxins (Mathew et al., 2006; Zodrow; Tanguay, 2003) , glucocorticoids (Mathew et al., 2007; Sengupta et al., 2012; Sharif et al., 2015) , and estrogenic endocrine-disrupting chemicals (Sun et al., 2019) , on the repair and regeneration of the caudal fin have been observed. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to investigate the effects of microplastics on caudal fin regeneration in zebrafish larvae after amputation. The results of this study will expand our knowledge about the toxicity of microplastics in aquatic organisms and will be helpful for a comprehensive ecotoxicological risk assessment of microplastics.

Polystyrene microspheres are frequently adopted as model particles for exploring the effects of microplastics, as polystyrene is one of the most produced polymers and commonly found in the aquatic environment (Jeong et al., 2016; Lu et al., 2016; Mattsson et al., 2015; Sussarellu et al., 2016; Veneman et al., 2017) . In the present study, microspheres with nominal diameters of 50 and 500 nm (Microspheres-Nanospheres, NY, USA) were chosen. Additionally, to explore the distribution of microplastics in zebrafish, green fluorescently labeled polystyrene beads with the same diameters (excitation/emission: 460/500 nm, Phosphorex, MA, USA) were used.

Wild-type AB and Tg (mpx:EGFP) zebrafish strains were obtained from the China Zebrafish Resource Center (Wuhan, China) and were maintained as previously described (Sun et al., 2019) . The embryos were collected (Westerfield, 2000) , and those developing normally were selected for the following test procedures. All of the following experiments were performed in compliance with the national guideline, "Laboratory animal -Guideline for ethical review of animal welfare (GB/T 35,892e2018)".

The chemical composition of microplastics was confirmed by Raman spectrometry (Lab-RAM HR Evolution, Horiba Jobin Yvon, France), and the size and morphology were verified by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (SU8100, Hitachi, Japan).
body_text.section: Preparation of microplastics suspensions and physicochemical characterization

body_text.text: The exposure solutions were always freshly prepared prior to exposure. The stock solutions (25 mg/mL) of the two microplastics were sonicated for 20 min and then used to produce the desired dilution series with charcoal-dechlorinated and UV-sterilized tap water. Considering the renewal interval of exposure media (as described below), the physicochemical characteristics of microplastics were tracked over a 24-h period with dynamic light scattering analysis (ZetaPals/BI-200SM, Brookhaven Instruments Corporation, USA).
body_text.section: Preparation of microplastics suspensions and physicochemical characterization

body_text.text: The embryos were incubated until hatching. At 72 h post fertilization (hpf), the hatched larvae were anesthetized with 0.02% tricaine, and caudal fin amputation was performed ( Fig. 1A ) (Mathew et al., 2006; Sun et al., 2019) . After amputation, the fish were transferred into a beaker containing microplastic suspensions (with a loading rate not exceeding 1 fish/10 mL) for one of four replicates per treatment. For 500-nm microspheres, the exposure concentrations were 0.1, 1 and 10 mg/L, while for 50-nm microspheres, the concentrations were 0.1 and 1 mg/L, as the mortality of the larvae that underwent amputation was increased at 10 mg/L in a preliminary study (data not shown). Control groups (with amputation) exposed to only dechlorinated tap water were included. Fish were allowed to regenerate for various times. The solutions were renewed daily, and the fish were not fed. For comparison, normal (no amputation) larvae in dechlorinated tap water were set up in parallel and were anesthetized and recovered in the same way.
body_text.section: Amputation of caudal fin and microplastic exposure

body_text.text: The larvae were anesthetized, and their caudal fins were imaged before amputation or at 24, 48, and 72 h post amputation (hpa). Five zebrafish from each of the four treatment replicates were sampled, and the regenerating fin area was quantified with ImageJ (NIH) in a blinded manner (Sun et al., 2019; Zodrow; Tanguay, 2003) .

The fins were amputated, and the larvae were treated. At 24, 48, and 72 hpa, nine larvae from each of the four replicates were transferred individually into wells of 96-well plates containing mL dechlorinated tap water. Locomotor behavior was assessed using a Zebralab Video-Track system (ViewPoint Life Science, France) following previously described methods (Sun et al., 2019; Sun et al., 2016) . Briefly, after 20 min of acclimation, the freeswimming activity under continuous visible light (20 min) and the response to a dark-to-light transition (dark-light-dark-light, 10 min each) were recorded.

The fins of larvae of the Tg (mpx:EGFP) transgenic zebrafish line (Renshaw et al., 2006) were amputated, and the larvae were exposed as described above. At different time points post amputation, three larvae from each replicate were sampled, and the numbers of fluorescent neutrophils that migrated to the caudal incision were quantified in a blinded manner (Sun et al., 2019).

The levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the larvae were determined by the 2 0 ,7 0 -dichlorodihydrofluoresceindiacetate (DCFH-DA) ROS assay kit (Beyotime Biotechnology, China). The fins were amputated, and the larvae exposed to microplastics. At 12 or hpa, five fish from each of the four replicates were transferred into a new dish, incubated with DCFH-DA (10 mM) for 20 min, and anesthetized for imaging with a fluorescence microscope at an excitation wavelength of 488 nm. The fluorescence intensity was quantified with ImageJ (NIH). In addition, twenty fish from each replicate were homogenized for one sample, and the resulting cell suspension was incubated with DCFH-DA (10 mM) for 20 min. The fluorescence was read with a fluorescence plate reader (excitation/emission: 485/530 nm). The total protein concentration was measured using the bicinchoninic acid (BCA) method (Sangon Biotech, China).

Oxidant/antioxidant status was also evaluated by determining the activities of antioxidant enzymes, including superoxide dismutase (SOD) and catalase (CAT), and the content of glutathione (GSH), an important antioxidant, and lipid peroxidation products, measured as the content of malonic dialdehyde (MDA). After amputation and exposure, twenty larvae from each replicate were pooled for one sample and then homogenized. After centrifugation, the supernatant was divided into several aliquots for subsequent measurement with commercial kits (Nanjing Jiancheng Bioengineering Institute, Nanjing, China).

After amputation and exposure, twenty larvae from each of four replicates were homogenized and then centrifuged to obtain the supernatant. The protein levels of cytokines, including Tnf-a, Il-10, and Nf-kB, and genes involved in tissue repair and regeneration, including Axin2, Bmp 4, Fgf20a, Raldh2, Shha, and Wnt10a, were determined by ELISA (Shanghai Enzyme-linked Biotechnology Co., China).
body_text.section: Determination of the protein levels of cytokines and regeneration-related genes after amputation

body_text.text: At 12 or 72 hpa, five exposed larvae from each replicate were incubated with a 5 mg/mL AO solution for 20 min in the dark. After rinsing, the fish were anesthetized, and apoptotic cells were identified with a fluorescence microscope with excitation wavelength of nm.

Amputation was performed, and the larvae were exposed to treatments. At 72 hpa, three larvae from each replicate were sampled for transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Fixation, embedding, and sectioning were performed (Rieger and Koster, 2007) , and ultrathin sections were then observed using a Hitachi Model H-7650 transmission electron microscope (Japan). Changes in the relative area of regenerating fin in larval zebrafish after microplastic exposure. The fish were sampled from the control group (Cont.), or the groups exposed to 50-nm microplastics at 0.1 and 1 mg/L (50e0.1 and 50e1) and to 500-nm microplastics at 0.1, 1 and 10 mg/L (500e0.1, 500e1 and 500e10). The fin areas of larvae exposed to microplastics were normalized to the corresponding controls at each regeneration stage (mean ± SEM, n ¼ 20). Asterisks denote a significant difference compared with the controls (one-way ANOVA followed by Dunnett's post hoc test, *p < 0.05 and **p < 0.01). (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)
body_text.section: Histological investigation of the regenerating fin

body_text.text: To qualitatively evaluate the uptake and biodistribution of microplastics, the fins were amputated, and the fish were exposed to green fluorescence microplastics, as described above. At different time points, five fish from each of four replicates were selected and rinsed with ultra-pure water before observation. Images were captured using a confocal laser microscope (Olympus FV1000) or a fluorescence microscope (Olympus CK31).

The fins were amputated, and the larvae were treated as described above. At 12 or 72 hpa, whole larvae were sampled, and twenty fish were homogenized for each of the four replicates per treatment. Total RNA was extracted using RNAiso Plus (Takara, Dalian, China). After RNA quantity and quality were assessed, RNA was reverse transcribed using the ReverTra Ace qPCR RT kit (Toyobo, Osaka, Japan), and the relative transcription of target genes was determined by quantitative real-time PCR with SYBR green detection (Toyobo, Osaka, Japan) (Sun et al., 2019) . The primer sequences for the target genes, including those involved in the signaling networks regulating fin regeneration, the immune response, and the antioxidant system, are summarized in Table S1 b-Actin was used as the internal reference gene. The target gene transcription was quantified using the comparative cycle threshold (Ct) method with adjustment of PCR efficiency (Livak and Schmittgen, 2001; Sun et al., 2019) .

In addition to measuring the transcriptional response of specific genes, this study was expanded with RNA-sequencing (RNA-seq). After amputation, the larvae were exposed to the two sizes of microplastics at 1 mg/L, as described above. At 12 or 72 hpa, the regenerating fins were cut at the ventral pigment gap for tailspecific analysis as previously described (Bugel et al., 2016) , and eighty isolated tails were homogenized for each of the four replicates. Total RNA was extracted as described above, and DNA contamination was removed. After RNA quantity and quality were assessed, the total RNA was used to generate the libraries using the NEBNext UltraTM RNA Library Prep Kit for Illumina (NEB, USA). The libraries were then quantified, and paired-end sequencing was performed on an Illumina platform. Raw reads were filtered, and the remaining clean data were further mapped to the reference genome by using HISAT2. Differential expression analysis was performed with DESeq. Functional enrichment analysis of differentially expressed genes (DEG), such as Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genome (KEGG), was performed with KOBAS. The richness factor was calculated as described previously (Peng et al., 2017) . Additionally, the results of RNA-seq analysis were verified with the qRT-PCR assay as mentioned above.

The data were initially checked for normality and homogeneity of variance. As the assumptions were met, the data were subjected to Student's t-test or one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Dunnett's post hoc test using SPSS 19.0 software. The critical value for statistical significance was defined as p < 0.05. Data analysis for RNA-seq was mentioned above.

The Raman spectra of the microplastics are shown in Fig. S1A , and the chemical composition of the two sizes of microplastics was confirmed by comparison with standard polystyrene. Additionally, as shown in the SEM images ( Fig. S1B) , the shape and nominal size of microplastics were in accordance with the manufacturer's information.

The time-dependent variations in the physicochemical parameters of microplastics are shown in Table S2 . As indicated by the hydrodynamic diameter, effective surface charge, and polydispersity index, the microplastics were distributed uniformly in the exposure media and were considerably stable over time.

Microplastic exposure significantly inhibited the caudal fin regeneration of zebrafish larvae (Figs. 1 and S2). At each regeneration stage observed, the area of the regenerating fin in larvae decreased with exposure to increasing concentrations of 50-nm microplastics, and significant differences were observed at 1 mg/ L. The inhibition caused by 500-nm microplastics exhibited a similar trend, and only 87.8% of fins were regenerated in the larvae exposed to 10 mg/L at 72 hpa. However, no difference in the inhibition of regeneration was observed between the two sizes of particles at the same concentration at each time point.
body_text.section: Effects of microplastics on caudal fin regeneration

body_text.text: During caudal fin regeneration, concentration-dependent decreases in swimming activities under continuous visible light or in response to the dark-to-light transition were observed for both sizes of microplastics at each time point, with significant differences from the control observed at concentrations of 1 mg/L and above (Fig. S3 ). The swimming speed of the larvae exposed to 50nm particles was slower than that of the larvae exposed to 500nm particles, but with no statistical significance.
body_text.section: Effects of microplastics on locomotor behavior

body_text.text: 3.4. Effects of microplastics on the mRNA and protein levels of genes involved in the signaling networks regulating fin regeneration Transcriptional changes in genes involved in the signaling networks regulating fin regeneration, including Wnt/b-catenin, bone morphogenic protein (BMP), fibroblast growth factor (FGF), insulinlike growth factor (IGF), Notch, retinoic acid (RA), activin, and Hedgehog (Hh) pathways, and of two markers of cell proliferation in the fin (mps1 and pcna), were shown in Fig. 2A . It was found that amputation induced the mRNA expression of most regenerationrelated genes. After microplastic exposure, the mRNA levels of most genes in the Wnt/b-catenin pathway were changed in a similar way at 12 hpa, with an increase followed by slight reduction. However, these genes tended to increase at 72 hpa with increasing concentrations, especially for in the 500-nm microplastic-treated groups. For instance, after exposure to 500-nm microplastics for 12 h, the mRNA level of axin2 was decreased concentrationdependently, with a significant difference at 10 mg/L. However, at 72 hpa, an increasing trend of axin2 was observed, which became significant at 10 mg/L. Most genes in other signaling pathways, including FGF, BMP, Hh, IGF, and activin, and two proliferation markers, appeared to have transcriptional profiles similar to that of the Wnt/b-catenin pathway. However, in the RA pathway, no change in rbp2a mRNA levels was observed at 12 hpa, while a significant decrease was found at 72 hpa after exposure to 500-nm microplastics. Regarding the Notch pathway, microplastic exposure led to no change in the mRNA levels of gata 6 and mfap4.
body_text.section: Effects of microplastics on locomotor behavior

body_text.text: Regarding the levels of proteins involved in fin regeneration, whereas the variability, relative fold-change and statistical significance differed, trends similar to the transcriptional responses were usually observed at 12 hpa ( Fig. 2B) . At 72 hpa, it seemed that the changes of some proteins followed that of gene transcription, such as Axin2. However, other proteins changed differently. For example, the protein level of Fgf20a tended to decline with increasing particle concentrations (although with no statistical significance), while the transcription increased in response to microplastic exposure, especially for the size of 500 nm.
body_text.section: Effects of microplastics on locomotor behavior

body_text.text: The neutrophil mitigation in the regenerating fin of zebrafish from the control and exposed groups were shown in Fig. 3A&B . The density of neutrophils recruited to the wound region was decreased in a concentration-dependent manner in the larvae exposed to both microplastics compared with the control larvae (Fig. 3B) . It was also found that exposure to 50-nm particles tended to result in fewer migrated neutrophils than did exposure to 500-nm particles, but with no statistical significance.
body_text.section: Effects of microplastics on the immune response

body_text.text: Regarding the mpx and mpeg1 genes, which correspond to neutrophils and macrophages, amputation significantly increased the mRNA level of mpx at 12 hpa and that of mpeg1 at 72 hpa (Fig. 3C) . However, the mRNA levels of both genes tended to decrease at 12 hpa after microplastic exposure but increased at 72 hpa.
body_text.section: Effects of microplastics on the immune response

body_text.text: As for genes encoding cytokines, except for il-1b at 12 hpa, the mRNA levels mostly tended to be induced after amputation (Fig. 3C ). After microplastic exposure for 12 h, the mRNA levels appeared to slightly increase at low concentrations but decreased at high concentrations. For instance, the mRNA levels of nf-kb2 were decreased concentration-dependently, with significant difference for exposure to 10 mg/L of 500-nm microplastics. However, most of these genes were transcriptionally induced by exposure at 72 hpa. For instance, the mRNA level of il-10 were increased with increasing particle concentration after exposure to both sizes of microplastics, with significant differences from the control observed at concentrations of 1 mg/L and above. Moreover, the protein levels of three cytokines (Il-10, Tnf-a, and Nf-kB) were determined (Fig. 3D) . Amputation increased the relative levels of all three cytokines at 12 hpa, which then declined at 72 hpa, returning to levels similar to that of the normal (no amputation) fish. Exposure to microplastics resulted in a similar pattern of change in these three cytokines, with a slight increase at low concentrations, followed by a reduction at higher concentrations. For example, at 12 and 72 hpa, the trends of concentrationdependent decline were observed for Nf-kB after exposure to 500-nm microplastics, which became significant at the highest concentration (10 mg/L).
body_text.section: Effects of microplastics on the immune response

body_text.text: Changes in ROS levels were determined with DCFH-DA probe assays (Fig. S4A&B) . Compared with the almost invisible green fluorescence in the normal (no amputation) fish, the trunk anterior to the amputation plane of larvae from the control groups at 12 hpa showed increased fluorescence and then appeared to fade away at 4) . Hash signs denote a significant difference from the normal fish (Student's t-test, #p < 0.05 and ##p < 0.01), and asterisks denote a significant difference from the controls (one-way ANOVA followed by Dunnett's test, *p < 0.05 and **p < 0.01) at 12 or 72 hpa. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.) 72 hpa, which was confirmed by the fluorescence intensity of whole fish homogenate. The increased fluorescence indicated that exposure to both sizes of microplastics likely induced ROS generation, which was especially evident at concentrations of mg/L and above.
body_text.section: Effects of microplastics on oxidant/antioxidant status

body_text.text: The ROS results were further supported by the activities of the antioxidant enzymes, including SOD and CAT, and the levels of GSH and MDA (Fig. 4B) . Amputation significantly induced the relative activities of both antioxidant enzymes and the relative content of GSH, especially at 12 hpa. After exposure, a slight increasing tendency followed by a significant decrease with increasing concentration was observed for both sizes of microplastics. For the lipid peroxidation product, exposure to both microplastics increased the MDA content in a concentration-dependent manner.
body_text.section: Effects of microplastics on oxidant/antioxidant status

body_text.text: Additionally, the mRNA levels of genes related to the antioxidant response were measured (Fig. 4A) . Similar to the enzyme activity results, amputation resulted in increases in the transcription of all four genes (cu/zn-sod, mn-sod, cat and gpx1a) at 12 hpa. The transcriptional responses of cu/zn-sod, mn-sod, and cat to microplastic exposure were similar to that of the enzyme activities at 12 hpa but contrasted the enzyme activities at 72 hpa. The mRNA level of gpx1a decreased after exposure to 500-nm microplastics for 72 h.
body_text.section: Effects of microplastics on oxidant/antioxidant status

body_text.text: As shown in Fig. S5 , apoptotic cells with green fluorescence after AO staining accumulated at the ventral corners of the regenerating fins and the ventral pigment gap. The fluorescence intensity anterior to the amputation plane tended to increase with increasing concentrations of both sizes, and significant differences were observed at both time points in the groups exposed to the highest concentration of 500-nm microplastics.
body_text.section: Effects of microplastics on cell apoptosis

body_text.text: Ultrastructural images of the larvae that underwent amputation from the control group demonstrated that the regenerating fin at 72 hpa was composed of fibrous tissue arranged in an orderly and compact fashion, typically with intact cell membranes, nuclei and cell organelles (Fig. S6) . After exposure to microplastics, discernible histological alterations were observed, particularly in fish from the highest exposure groups. For instance, the amputation plane of larvae exposed to 500-nm microplastics at 10 mg/L was characterized by damaged mitochondria with empty matrices or membrane breakage, and the endoplasmic reticulum in some fish was 4) . Hash signs denote a significant difference from normal fish (Student's t-test, #p < 0.05 and ##p < 0.01), and asterisks denote a significant difference from the controls (one-way ANOVA followed by Dunnett's test, *p < 0.05 and **p < 0.01). (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.) destroyed or became swollen.
body_text.section: Histological investigation of the regenerating fin

body_text.text: The distribution and accumulation of microplastics are shown in Fig. S7&8 . No visible fluorescence was observed in the fish from the unexposed groups (data not shown). After exposure for 24 h, green fluorescence was detected in the larvae that underwent amputation and exposure to both sizes of microplastics, even at the lowest concentration; and fluorescence levels tended to increase in a concentration-and time-dependent manner. The yolk sac (before resorption), pericardium, and gastrointestinal tract were the predominant tissues in which the particles accumulated. Additionally, low fluorescence was visible around the wound site (Fig. S8 ), implying the interaction between particles and the tissue around the amputated plane. Strong fluorescence was also observed in the eye and head of larvae exposed to 50-nm particles, while few 500-nm particles were localized in these regions (Fig. S7) .

Transcriptomic analyses were further performed (Supplemental dataset 1), and RNA-seq data were confirmed by qRT-PCR ( Fig. S9) . According to principal component analysis (PCA) (Fig. 5B) , the samples from different treatments were clustered into distinct groups with small variations, especially at 12 hpa, which not only confirmed the impacts of amputation but more importantly suggested the specific effects caused by microplastics of different sizes. Furthermore, compared with the results at 12 hpa, the normal (no amputation) groups at 72 hpa clustered differently than the amputation groups, whether exposed to microplastics or not, implying that the impacts of microplastic exposure weakened over the regenerative process.
body_text.section: Transcriptomic response in the regenerating fin of larvae

body_text.text: Moreover, 1066 genes were differentially expressed (FC (fold changes) 2 and FDR (false discovery rate) < 0.01) at 12 hpa; however, fewer DEGs (differentially expressed genes) were found at 72 hpa (Fig. 5C ). The decline in the number of DEGs over the regeneration process was consistent with macroscopic observations, as fin regeneration was nearly restored in three days.
body_text.section: Transcriptomic response in the regenerating fin of larvae

body_text.text: After exposure to 1 mg/L microplastics for 12 h, 534 and 121 DEGs were observed in the groups treated with 50-nm and 500-nm particles, respectively (Fig. 5C ). In contrast, 72 h of exposure yielded fewer DEGs in the 50-nm particle-treated groups and more DEGs in the 500-nm particle-treated groups. Fewer DEGs were found after microplastic exposure than after amputation, and more importantly, most of the DEGs were downregulated, in contrast to the large number of upregulated transcripts after amputation, suggesting the strong inhibitory effects of microplastic exposure on gene expression. Moreover, exposure to 50-nm microplastics resulted in more DEGs than exposure to 500-nm microplastics at 12 hpa; however, the opposite result was observed at 72 hpa, implying the size-dependent effects of microplastic exposure.
body_text.section: Transcriptomic response in the regenerating fin of larvae

body_text.text: As shown in the Venn diagram ( Fig. 5D ), it is intriguing to note that a large proportion of microplastic-induced DEGs was also found in the control (vs. normal) group, especially at 12 hpa, suggesting that the genes affected by microplastic exposure were most likely involved in the fin regeneration process.
body_text.section: Transcriptomic response in the regenerating fin of larvae

body_text.text: In addition, lists of genes with known roles in fin regeneration, such as those in IGF, Wnt, RA, Notch, FGF, Hh and BMP signaling, as well as the cytokine genes and those involved in oxidative stress (Nauroy et al., 2019; Rabinowitz et al., 2017; Rehberger et al., 2017) were manually curated (Fig. 6) . It was clearly showed that these specific pathways related to tissue regeneration were up-regulated after amputation (especially at 12 hpa), while down-regulated after exposure to microplastics (especially with 50-nm), which paralleled nicely with the results mentioned above. Similarly, RNA-seq result of genes related to cytokines and oxidative stress, which coupled with the results of qRT-PCR, protein expression or enzyme activity, provided further support for the physiological responses.
body_text.section: Transcriptomic response in the regenerating fin of larvae

body_text.text: The top 20 enriched pathways as determined by KEGG analysis are shown as a bubble chart in Fig. S10 . It was revealed that amputation changed the pathways that were mostly involved in biosynthesis and metabolism, while other pathways, such as the PPAR signaling pathway, extracellular matrix (ECM)-receptor interaction and peroxisome, were also included at 12 hpa.
body_text.section: Transcriptomic response in the regenerating fin of larvae

body_text.text: Pathways involved in biosynthesis and metabolism were also significantly enriched after microplastic exposure. Moreover, some specific pathways were observed. For example, the PPAR signaling pathway and retinol metabolism at 12 hpa and the PPAR signaling pathway, ECM-receptor, and Hh signaling pathway at 72 hpa were among the most enriched pathways after exposure to 50-nm microplastics.
body_text.section: Transcriptomic response in the regenerating fin of larvae

body_text.text: Microplastic pollution represents a global challenge affecting aquatic ecosystems, which has driven intense study concerning the Fig. 6 . Heatmaps illustrating the genes identified in the RNA-seq analysis (FC 1.3 after any treatment) and with known roles in fin regeneration, as well as the cytokine genes and those involved in oxidative stress. (A) Cytokine genes. (B) Genes involved in oxidative stress. (C) Regeneration-related genes. Norm. vs. Cont.: # FDR <0.05 and ## FDR <0.01; Cont. vs. 50e1 or 500e1: * FDR <0.05 and ** FDR <0.01. exposure and effects of microplastics on aquatic organisms (Franzellitti et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2018) . Although the ingestion of microplastics by a wide array of species across different trophic levels has been well documented (Auta et al., 2017; Ivleva et al., 2017) , relatively less effort has been devoted to investigating the effects on aquatic organisms, particularly fish (Avery-Gomm et al., 2018; de Sa et al., 2018) . In the present study, it was demonstrated for the first time that microplastic exposure results in the inhibition of the regenerative capacity of zebrafish, morphologically and functionally, which highlighted the importance of the response of injured organisms in ecotoxicological risk assessment.

Following amputation, larval zebrafish regenerate the caudal fin by a complex but well-orchestrated process termed epimorphic regeneration, and the size and shape of the fin is restored within 3 days (Wehner and Weidinger, 2015; Yoshinari and Kawakami, 2011) . A variety of signaling pathways, including Wnt/b-catenin, FGF, BMP, Hh, RA, IGF, Notch, etc., have been found to be required for fin regeneration (Sehring et al., 2016; Wehner; Weidinger, 2015) . In the present study, most regeneration-related genes measured were found to be changed after exposure to microplastics, not only at the mRNA level but also at the protein level. For example, amputation induced the gene and protein expression of most of the regeneration-related genes, which were downregulated after microplastic exposure, as shown in Fig. 2 . Therefore, the inhibited fin regeneration caused by microplastic exposure might be a consequence of the intervention of these regenerationregulating signaling pathways.

There is substantial evidence that the immune system has a fundamental impact on tissue repair and regeneration, in addition to the defense against the invasion of microorganisms (Eming et al., 2009; LeBert; Huttenlocher, 2014; Mescher et al., 2017) . After amputation, the transcriptional responses of immune-related genes were found to be changed, which was further confirmed by the results of ELISA in the present study. For example, the gene and protein expression of il-10 was found to be induced at 12 hpa. Amputation significantly induced the mRNA expression mpx, a gene specific to neutrophils, which is in agreement with the observation of neutrophil migration in the transgenic fish. However, microplastic exposure tended to affect these genes in a converse manner, especially at 12 hpa. For instance, mpx was transcriptionally suppressed in exposed larvae, and accordingly, fewer migrated neutrophils were found (Fig. 3) .

The alteration of the immune response induced by the exposure to microplastics with different type of polymers has been well documented in previous studies with zebrafish, as well as in other organisms (da Costa et al., 2016; Jin et al., 2018; Lu et al., 2016; Tang et al., 2018; Veneman et al., 2017; von Moos et al., 2012; Wan et al., 2019) . For example, waterborne exposure to polystyrene microplastics induced inflammatory responses in the gastrointestinal tract and liver of zebrafish, accompanied by histopathological changes, microbiota dysbiosis and metabolomic alterations (Jin et al., 2018; Lu et al., 2016; Wan et al., 2019) . Similarly, the injection of polystyrene microplastics (700 nm) induced the systemic immune response of zebrafish larvae (Veneman et al., 2017) . However, in coral, immune capacity was significantly suppressed after exposure to polystyrene microplastics with a diameter of 1.0 mm (Tang et al., 2018) . In the present study, given the interrelation of tissue repair or regeneration and immunity, the changed immune responses caused by microplastic exposure are likely involved in the inhibition of fin regeneration.

ROS function as signaling molecules that regulate a broad range of biological processes. Wounds result in ROS production and are essential for subsequent regeneration in zebrafish (Gauron et al., 2013) . The observed oxidant/antioxidant status in the controls, as indicated by mRNA level and enzyme activity, as well as ROS levels and lipid peroxidation product content (Fig. 4 & S4) , were completely consistent with the expectation. On the other hand, exposure to xenobiotics could stimulate ROS production, and excess ROS results in oxidative damage and further impairments at the cellular or physiological level. Recently, increasing evidence suggests that oxidative damage might be an important mechanism of toxicity for microplastic exposure (SAPEA, 2019; Franzellitti et al., 2019; Jeong et al., 2016) . Oxidative stress induced by microplastics has been reported in zebrafish following larval (Chen et al., 2017) or adult exposure (Lei et al., 2018; Lu et al., 2016) and was found to persist in offspring after parental exposure (Pitt et al., 2018b) . The results observed here clearly indicated that microplastic exposure significantly changed the oxidant/antioxidant status of the fish in the amputation groups (Fig. 4&S4) . Specifically, microplastic exposure induced the production of ROS; low levels of ROS activate antioxidant enzymes, while excess ROS tend to decrease antioxidant capacity and result in the accumulation of peroxidation products. However, in contrast to the enzyme activities, the mRNA levels of antioxidant enzymes were found to be increased at 72 hpa as part of a compensatory response. Since ROS signaling is concentration dependent (Gauron et al., 2013) , the change in oxidant/ antioxidant status might contribute to the inhibitory effects of microplastics on fin regeneration. Moreover, given that cell apoptosis was supposed to be induced by a high ROS level (at least partially), the change in the amount of apoptotic cells in the trunk (Fig. S5) , accompanied by histological alterations on the amputation plane, such as damaged mitochondria (Fig. S6) , provided further support for this argument.

To provide a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the inhibitory effects of microplastics, RNA-seq was performed on the regenerating fin. It was interesting to note that in contrast to the large number of upregulated transcripts after amputation, the major DEGs induced by microplastic exposure were downregulated (Fig. 5C ). Moreover, the comparative analysis of DEGs with a Venn diagram clearly revealed a high degree of similarity between the amputation-induced and microplasticsinduced DEGs (Fig. 5D ). All these observations led to the proposal that transcriptional modulation (generally downregulation) of these genes involved in fin regeneration could be responsible for the inhibitory effects of microplastics on fin regeneration. RNA-seq results of genes which were suggested to be specifically linked to tissue repair and regeneration ( Fig. 6) , as well as those related to cytokines and oxidative stress, were found to be consistent with the expectation. It was also important to note that size-dependent effects were demonstrated from RNA-seq results, although this effect was not detected with the other endpoints assessed in this study.

Furthermore, functional analyses with KEGG ( Fig. S10 ) revealed that the primary pathways involved in biosynthesis and metabolism were enriched not only in response to amputation but also in response to microplastic exposure. The noticeable changes in molecules related to metabolism in the transcriptomic responses to amputation observed here were consistent with previous studies conducted using microarray (Mathew et al., 2009; Yoshinari et al., 2009) . For instance, the upregulated genes related to metabolism represented the most abundant functional group (40%) in the regenerating fin fold of zebrafish larvae (Yoshinari et al., 2009) . Exposure to the microplastics with different polymers has been extensively demonstrated to modulate metabolism in fish and other organisms (Brandts et al., 2018; LeMoine et al., 2018; Lu et al., 2016; Mattsson et al., 2015; Sussarellu et al., 2016; Wan et al., 2019) . For example, a whole animal transcriptomic approach found that the ingestion of polyethylene microplastics (10e45 mm) by developing zebrafish caused profound changes in cellular metabolic pathways, and the majority of these genes were downregulated (LeMoine et al., 2018). Another study reported that metabolomic profiles were disturbed in the liver of zebrafish and suggested that the alteration of lipid and energy metabolism was the primary response to the exposure of polystyrene microplastics (70 nm and 5 mm) (Lu et al., 2016) .

Additionally, other pathways, such as the ECM-receptor interaction, were enriched in response to amputation (Fig. S10) , as reported previously (Mathew et al., 2009; Nauroy et al., 2019; Yoshinari et al., 2009) . The ECM is believed to play a critical role in tissue repair and regeneration, and its misregulation could ultimately result in the inhibition of cell migration and the distribution of signaling molecules (Andreasen et al., 2007; Nauroy et al., 2019) . The ECM-receptor interaction pathway was also significantly enriched after exposure to 50-nm microplastics for 72 h. Moreover, the pathways essential for fin regeneration, such as retinol metabolism and Hh signaling, were impacted after microplastic exposure ( Fig. S10 ). It should be emphasized that only regenerating caudal fins were sampled for RNA-seq, yet multiple metabolic pathways, rather than those specific to wound repair and regeneration, were predominantly modulated. It would be expected that if the exposure triggered a shift in energy allocation in response to xenobiotic stress, the metabolic expenditures for tissue repair and regeneration should be reduced correspondingly. Therefore, the changes of metabolic pathways, which mostly considered as general responses, should be underlined in future regeneration studies.

The fluorescent polystyrene assay confirmed that both sizes of particles could be taken up by larval zebrafish (Fig. S7) , and the size significantly influenced further internalization and biodistribution, as previously reported (Pitt et al., 2018a; van Pomeren et al., 2017) . Oral exposure (via the gastrointestinal tract) and dermal exposure (via the epidermis or gills) are considered to be the most likely routes for the uptake of polystyrene particles (25 and 50 nm) from the surrounding medium (van Pomeren et al., 2017) . However, the presence of fluorescence in the area of the regenerating caudal fin (Fig. S8 ), nevertheless faint, suggested that the tissue of the amputated plane was penetrable and might be an additional route for microplastic uptake. All these exposure routes might account for the observed fin regeneration.

The results showed that microplastic exposure inhibited the regenerative capacity of zebrafish larvae that underwent amputation. The signaling networks regulating fin regeneration, as well as ROS signaling and immune responses, were altered after microplastic exposure and were speculated to contribute to the inhibitory effects. Additionally, transcriptomic analyses revealed that genes related to fin regeneration were transcriptionally modulated in response to microplastic exposure, and metabolic pathways were found to be extensively involved. Size-dependent effects were implied from RNA-seq data and deserve further exploration. Given that the toxic effects of microplastics were previously generally assessed in the context of healthy organisms, this study expanded our understanding of the potential effects of microplastic pollution and was likely to pave the way toward a more definite answer to this global problem.

FIGREF0.text: Effects of microplastics on caudal fin regeneration in larval zebrafish. (A) Schematic of caudal fin amputation. The red dashed line indicates the plane of amputation. (B)

FIGREF1.text: Effects of microplastics on the mRNA and protein levels of genes involved in the signaling networks regulating fin regeneration. (A) Transcriptional changes in genes in the main pathways including Wnt/b-catenin, BMP, FGF, IGF, Notch, RA, activin and Hh, as well as two proliferation markers (mps1 and pcna). The average transcript values relative to the normal fish at each time point are indicated by the color gradient and log2 transformed (n ¼ 4). (B) Changes in the protein levels involved in fin regeneration. The protein values relative to the normal fish (Norm.) at each time point are presented as boxplots (n ¼

FIGREF2.text: Effects of microplastics on the immune response of zebrafish larvae after amputation. (A) The caudal fin of Tg (mpx:EGFP) transgenic zebrafish. The red dashed line indicates the plane of amputation, and the black dotted line indicates the regions used to quantify neutrophils migration to the wound site. (B) Changes of the number of neutrophils in the regenerating fin. The results are presented as the mean ± SEM (n ¼ 12). (C) Changes in the transcription of genes related to the immune system. The average transcript values relative to normal fish are indicated by the color gradient and log2 transformed (n ¼ 4). (D) Changes in the protein levels of Il-10, Nf-kb, and Tnf-a. The protein values relative to normal fish are presented as boxplots (n ¼

FIGREF3.text: Effects of microplastics on the oxidant/antioxidant status of zebrafish larvae after amputation. (A) Changes in the transcription of genes involved in antioxidant response. The average transcript values relative to normal fish are indicated by the color gradient and log2 transformed (n ¼ 4). (B) Changes in the activities of antioxidant enzymes (SOD and CAT), and in the contents of GSH and MDA. The values relative to normal fish are presented as boxplots (n ¼ 4). Hash signs denote a significant difference from normal fish (Student's t-test, #p < 0.05), and asterisks denote a significant difference from the controls (one-way ANOVA followed by Dunnett's test, *p < 0.05). (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

FIGREF4.text: Transcriptomic response of the regenerating fin in the zebrafish larvae following microplastic exposure at 12 and 72 hpa. (A) Schematic of the isolation of the regenerating fin for transcriptomic analysis. Tails were cut at the pigment gap (red dashed line). (B) PCA of RNA-seq data. The points represent biological replicates (n ¼ 4). (C) Volcano plots showing the relative abundances of transcripts and the numbers of DEGs (FC 2 and FDR< 0.01). (D) Venn diagram of DEGs. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)
